issues.description: The problem statement's UML and textual description declare acceptSupplyDelivery to take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) but the example usage in Main (template) and the reference implementation use a three-parameter signature (ingredient name, price, quantity). This mismatch between the specified signature and both the template example and solution implementation will confuse students about the correct method signature to implement and may lead to failing tests or compilation errors if they follow the UML/text literally.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the intended acceptSupplyDelivery signature consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the UML and problem text to specify the three-parameter signature acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) (and remove the unused supplier parameter from the description), or (B) update the template Main and solution to use the four-parameter signature acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity) and adjust implementations/tests to make use of the supplier parameter. Choose one variant and apply it consistently in the problem statement, template examples, and reference solution.

issues.description: The problem text instructs students to initialize a final Stock field in the SealSaloon constructor (instance initialization), but elsewhere (explicit note) it requires the stock attribute to be static (shared across instances). Initializing a static final field in an instance constructor is not appropriate in Java and conflicts with the later requirement that stock be static. This contradiction can confuse students about whether stock should be an instance or static field and where it should be initialized.
issues.suggested_fix: Clarify and align the requirement: either (A) make stock an instance final field and initialize it in the constructor (remove the 'stock must be static' note), or (B) require stock to be static (shared) and instruct students to initialize it at the declaration site or in a static initializer rather than in the instance constructor. Update the problem text to explicitly state how and where the static final stock should be initialized to avoid confusion.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML and textual description) specifies acceptSupplyDelivery to take four parameters (supplier name, ingredient name, price, quantity) — i.e., acceptSupplyDelivery(String, String, int, int). Both the provided template usage (Main.java) and the solution implementation (SealSaloon.java) use a different signature that takes only three parameters (ingredient name, price, quantity) — acceptSupplyDelivery(String name, int price, int quantity). This mismatch (presence/absence of the supplier parameter and differing parameter names) creates confusion: students following the textual/UML specification will expect a 4-parameter method, while the starter/example code and reference solution use a 3-parameter method. The discrepancy makes it unclear which method signature to implement and how to use the method in Main, adding unnecessary cognitive load.
issues.suggested_fix: Make the acceptSupplyDelivery signature consistent across all artifacts. Either (A) update the problem statement/UML to specify the 3-parameter form used in the code (acceptSupplyDelivery(String ingredientName, int price, int quantity)) and clarify that supplier is not required, or (B) change the template and solution code (and example Main calls) to implement the 4-parameter form (acceptSupplyDelivery(String supplierName, String ingredientName, int price, int quantity)) to match the current textual/UML description. Ensure parameter names in code and the problem text match to avoid further confusion.
